title: Unilever pledges to cut plastic in move to stay relevant among younger customers
text:
The British and Dutch consumer-goods giant, which produces about 700,000 tons of new plastic per year, said it will halve its use of new plastic by 2025 in favour of recycled plastic and alternative materials. CEO Alan Jope also called on U.K. councils to harmonize recycling policies to simplify the process for consumers. (The Logic)

Talking point: Unilever is the latest company to say it will reduce its use of new plastic as environmental sustainability emerges as a growing consumer demand. It also comes as Generation Z gets a reputation for socially conscious consumption; a January study found reducing single-use plastics was among the factors the younger generation prioritizes when picking between brands. Procter & Gamble said in April it would halve its use of new plastics by 2030, and Nestlé announced plans to make all its packaging renewable or recyclable by 2025. But in Canada, industry efforts to decrease the use of new plastic have been hampered by a larger disposal problem—China has cut its imports of scrap plastic by 96 per cent, leaving Canada’s recycling industry struggling to cope amid costs rising by as much as 40 per cent.
